questions.text: Which of the following macroscopic features is most characteristic of Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis?

choices.text: Continuous inflammation from the rectum extending proximally
Erythematous, granular mucosa with superficial ulcerations
Deep, punched-out ulcers with transmural inflammation
Thickened bowel wall and mesenteric fat wrapping

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Thickened bowel wall and mesenteric fat wrapping

¬†

Explanation:

Thickened Bowel Wall and Mesenteric Fat Wrapping are typical features of Crohn‚Äôs disease. The bowel wall becomes thickened due to transmural inflammation, and there is often ‚Äúcreeping fat‚Äù around the bowel.


Macroscopic features of UC and Crohn‚Äôs:

Feature

Ulcerative Colitis

Crohn's Disease

Location

Rectum and colon, continuous; does not involve small intestine.

Any part of the GI tract; often the terminal ileum, colon; can involve small bowel and upper GI tract.

Extent

Continuous inflammation; no skip lesions.

Patchy inflammation with skip lesions between affected areas.

Appearance

Erythematous, granular mucosa; superficial ulcers.

Deep, serpiginous ulcers, especially on the mesenteric side.

Wall Involvement

Mucosa and submucosa only.

Transmural inflammation through all bowel layers.

Strictures

Rare.

Common due to transmural inflammation and fibrosis.

Fistulas

Rare, usually perianal.

Common, including between bowel loops and adjacent organs.

Fat Wrapping

Absent.

Present; "creeping fat" around the bowel wall.

Additional Features

-

Thickened bowel wall; thickened mesentery with enlarged lymph nodes.

Images

¬†

¬†

questions.text:
A 52-year-old male with a history of ulcerative colitis presents with severe abdominal pain and distention, fever, and tachycardia. He appears ill and is in significant discomfort. Lab tests show leukocytosis and electrolyte imbalances. An X-ray of the abdomen is taken. Which of the following surgical procedures is the most appropriate for this patient?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Total Abdominal Colectomy with End Ileostomy
Diverting Loop Ileostomy with Colonic Lavage

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Total Abdominal Colectomy with End Ileostomy

¬†

Explanation:


The patient's severe symptoms and lab abnormalities, along with X-ray findings of significant colonic dilation, suggest a critical condition like toxic megacolon.

  • The most appropriate surgical procedure is Total Abdominal Colectomy with End Ileostomy, as it has been associated with lower mortality compared to segmental colectomy, especially in the presence of colonic perforation or necrosis.


¬†

Management of Toxic megacolon:

Therapies
  • IBD-Related: Intravenous glucocorticoids (e.g., hydrocortisone 100 mg every 6-8 hours) as first-line therapy; infliximab or cyclosporine if no response within 3 days
  • C. difficile Colitis: Stop inciting antibiotics; steroids not used; metronidazole, vancomycin, or fidaxomicin for medical therapy; fecal microbial transplantation considered in some cases

Surgical Indications
  • Absolute indications: Perforation, life-threatening hemorrhage, worsening toxicity, worsening dilatation
  • IBD: Colectomy if no improvement after 24-48 hours; subtotal colectomy preferred for emergency surgery
  • C. difficile: Surgery for perforation, necrosis, or severe complications; early colectomy reduces the mortality rate

¬†

Procedure

Indications

Advantages

Disadvantages

Total Abdominal Colectomy with End Ileostomy

¬†

Colonic perforation, necrosis, abdominal compartment syndrome

Resolves abdominal compartment syndrome, lower mortality compared to segmental resection

More invasive, irreversible stomas in many cases

Diverting Loop Ileostomy with Colonic Lavage

¬†

No perforation, necrosis, or compartment syndrome

Minimally invasive, higher likelihood of stoma reversal

May leave inflamed colon, slower recovery, potential ongoing critical illness

¬†

Segmental Colectomy (Option A) is associated with higher mortality in fulminant C. difficile colitis and is no longer recommended.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents with severe abdominal distension and diarrhea. His vitals show a heart rate of 125 beats/min, fever of 38.9¬∞C, and a white blood cell count of 13,800/microL. A radiograph reveals colonic dilation of 7 cm. Which of the following additional findings would not confirm the diagnosis of toxic megacolon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anemia

¬†

Explanation:

  • Anemia is one of the systemic signs considered in the diagnostic criteria but does not fulfill the additional systemic toxicity criteria (which are altered sensorium, dehydration, electrolyte disturbances, or hypotension).
  • Thus, anemia alone would not be sufficient to confirm toxic megacolon when assessing the systemic toxicity criteria.
    ¬†

¬†

Diagnosis and Evaluation of Toxic Megacolon

Diagnosis Criteria

Radiographic Evidence: Colonic dilation (diameter >6 cm)

¬†

PLUS at least three of the following:

  • Fever >38¬∫C
  • Heart rate >120 beats/min
  • Neutrophilic leukocytosis >10,500/microL
  • Anemia
¬†

PLUS at least one of the following:

  • Dehydration
  • Altered sensorium (Option B)
  • Electrolyte disturbances (Option D)
  • Hypotension (Option C)

Differential Diagnosis
  • Congenital megacolon (Hirschsprung's disease).
  • Acquired megacolon (chronic constipation).
  • Chagas megacolon.
  • Colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie syndrome).
  • Diffuse gastrointestinal dysmotility.
  • Acute colonic obstruction from diverticulitis, volvulus, tumors.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient diagnosed with mild Crohn's disease affecting the ileocecal region presents to your clinic. The patient has mild symptoms with no significant systemic involvement. What is the most appropriate first-line drug to prescribe for this patient to induce remission in mild Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Budesonide

¬†

Explanation:

  • Budesonide is a first-line treatment for inducing remission in mild to moderate Crohn's disease, especially when the disease is localized in the ileocecal region.
  • It is a corticosteroid with a high first-pass metabolism, resulting in fewer systemic side effects than corticosteroids like prednisone.

¬†

Category

Mild Crohn's Disease

Moderate to Severe Crohn's Disease

Induction Therapy
  • First-line: Budesonide¬†(Option D) (preferred for ileocecal disease)or aminosalicylates (e.g., mesalamine).
  • Prednisone¬†(Option A) for those who do not respond to budesonide.
  • Alternative: Enteral nutrition.
  • First-line: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone for short term) or biologics
    Anti-TNF agents (Infliximab (Option C), Adalimumab)
  • Anti-integrin therapy (Vedolizumab)
  • Anti-interleukin therapy (Ustekinumab)
  • Combination therapy: Anti-TNF agents plus immunomodulators (Azathioprine, 6-MP) (Option B)

Maintenance Therapy
  • First-line: Continue aminosalicylates if effective.
  • Alternative: Thiopurines (azathioprine, 6-MP) for patients intolerant to aminosalicylates.
  • Anti-TNF monotherapy: Long-term for maintaining remission.
  • Combination therapy: Anti-TNF agents with immunomodulators (for severe cases or history of nonresponse to biologics).
  • Continue anti-integrin or anti-interleukin agents for those induced by these therapies

Monitoring
  • Regular follow-up to monitor symptoms and inflammation.
  • Ileocolonoscopy 6-12 months post-remission. Drug level monitoring and fecal calprotectin to assess mucosal healing.

¬†

questions.text: A patient with chronic ulcerative colitis who had undergone total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis has come to the department complaining of diarrhoea, abdominal pain, fever and malaise. On examination, hematochezia is noted. What is the first line of treatment here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Antibiotic therapy

¬†

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of pouchitis.
  • The first line of treatment for pouchitis is antibiotic therapy.

¬†

Definition:

  • Pouchitis is an inflammatory condition affecting the ileal pouch and continent ileostomy reservoirs.
  • It occurs in 30% to 55% of cases.

¬†

Etiology:

  • The actual etiology is unknown.
  • It may be due to fecal stasis in the pouch, but emptying studies are not confirmatory.

¬†

Clinical features:

  • Diarrhea
  • Hematochezia
  • Fever
  • Pain abdomen
  • Malaise

¬†

Investigation and diagnosis: Endoscopy and biopsy

¬†

Management:

  • First line: Antibiotic therapy using metronidazole +/- ciprofloxacin. Oral preparations or enemas can be given.
  • In chronic pouchitis, ongoing suppressive therapy is to be given.
  • Salicylate and corticosteroids can also be used.
  • In case of refractory disease, normal flora in the intestine is reintroduced with the help of probiotics (Option C) and/ or an elemental diet.
  • Biological agents (Option B) like TNFùõÇ (infliximab, vedolizumab, ustekinumab)
  • Pouch excision (Option D) is done in cases of chronic pouchitis.

¬†

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a long-standing history of chronic inflammatory bowel disease presents for routine follow-up. He undergoes a colonoscopy, during which suspicious lesions are identified. A biopsy confirms the presence of malignancy. Which of the following types of cancer is more commonly associated with Crohn's disease than with ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Small intestine carcinoma

¬†

Explanation:

  • Small intestine cancers are more prone to Crohn‚Äôs disease than ulcerative colitis.
  • Small bowel adenocarcinoma is a rare complication associated with Crohn‚Äôs disease.
  • This is because the small bowel (ileum) is the most common part of the intestine affected by Crohn‚Äôs disease.

¬†

Risk factors of carcinoma in ulcerative colitis:

  • Pancolonic disease
  • Duration (Long-standing disease)
  • Dysplasias
  • Left-sided colitis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Hereditary colon cancer
  • Young age

¬†

Features of colitis-associated carcinoma:

  • Age group >30 years
  • Due to prolonged colitis
  • Develops from colitis ‚Üí dysplasia ‚Üí carcinoma
  • Dysplasia seen here is flat dysplasia
  • Pancolonic disease: multicentric and infiltrative
  • Increased mortality
  • Endoscopic removal or colonoscopy is done
  • Interval cancers are possible

NOTE:¬†

  • Risk for colonic carcinoma: CD=UC
  • Risk for small bowel malignancy: CD>UC
  • Risk for Cholangiocarcinoma: UC>CD

Colon carcinoma (Option A) is a complication of both Crohn‚Äôs and ulcerative colitis with equal occurrences.

¬†

Cholangiocarcinoma (Option C) is associated with ulcerative colitis. The risk factor here is primary sclerosing cholangitis.

¬†

Gastric cancer (Option D) is not associated with Ulcerative colitis or Crohn‚Äôs disease. It is rather associated with chronic peptic ulcers.

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following would be a differentiating feature of Colitis-associated colon carcinoma (CAC) from sporadic colon cancer?

choices.text: Sporadic colon cancer develops due to chronic inflammation and dysplasia
CAC is more common after the age of 30
Sporadic colon cancer is associated with young individuals

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CAC is more common after the age of 30 years

¬†

Explanation:

Colitis-associated colon carcinoma (CAC) is more common after 30 years and sporadic colon cancer is most common in the 8th decade.

¬†

Colitis-associated colon cancer

Sporadic colon cancer
  • Age group >30 years
  • Due to prolonged colitis
  • Develops from colitis to dysplasia to carcinoma
  • Dysplasia seen here is flat dysplasia
  • Pancolonic disease: multicentric and infiltrative
  • Increased mortality (Option B)
  • Endoscopic removal or colonoscopy is done
  • Interval cancers are possible
  • Age group > 50 years¬†(Option D)
  • Most common in 8th decade
  • Most common site is the sigmoid colon, with left-side predominance
  • Usually arises from an adenomatous polyp (Option A)


¬†

¬†

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male comes to the hospital complaining of intermittent pain in the anal region and intermittent diarrhea for 6 months. On examination, he was found to have complex perianal fistulas bilaterally, with skin tags, as shown in the image. His blood investigations reveal anemia. What could be the possible diagnosis leading to this?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Crohn‚Äôs disease of anorectum

¬†

Explanation:

Crohn‚Äôs disease of the anorectum presents with multiple complex fistulae mostly bilateral and with purplish skin tags that give an ‚Äúelephant ear" appearance.

  • Clinical features:
    • Bilaterally located complex anal fistula
    • Elephant ear type large skin tags-edematous and purplish.
    • Broad-based anal fissures away from the midline
    • Anorectal abscess, which may rupture and lead to fistulae
    • Ulceration

¬†

  • Treatment:
    • Control of infection, treatment of underlying mucosal disease, and sphincter preservation.
    • Drain abscesses, if any, to prevent the development of perineal sepsis.
    • Medical therapy: antibiotics (metronidazole), immunomodulators, and biologic agents (ANF alpha agents: infliximab, adalimumab); (salicylates and/or corticosteroid enemas for proctitis)
    • Early fecal diversion for anovaginal fistula.
    • Endoanal mucosal advancement flap repair.
    • Anal strictures may be dilated if symptomatic.

Ulcerative colitis (Option B) commonly presents with bloody diarrhea but does not cause perianal disease with fissures or tags.

¬†

Carcinoma rectum (Option C) may present with bleeding per rectum and will have a complex of symptoms like weight loss, early morning diarrhea, and pain which is a late symptom. A full colorectal examination and a CT are necessary here.

¬†

Hemorrhoids (Option D) may be present in Crohn‚Äôs of the anorectum but not with the above-mentioned clinical features. There won't usually be anal pain.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A patient with a history of ulcerative colitis (UC) has undergone a total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (TPA + IPAA) as part of their treatment. Which of the following is not a possible complication of the procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Peritonitis

¬†

Explanation:

Peritonitis is a complication of inflammatory bowel disease and not of the surgery. It is caused due to abscesses or fistulae in the intestine due to the disease.

¬†

Complications of TPA+IPAA:

  • Pouchitis (Option B): Most common postoperative complication
  • Pouch failure
  • Risk of adhesions or small bowel obstruction
  • Pouch-related fistula (pouch vaginal)
  • Pelvic sepsis (Option C)
  • Strictures
  • Anastomosis and pouch line leaks (Option A)¬†
  • Crohn‚Äôs disease de novo

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is the definitive management of Ulcerative colitis?

choices.text: Total Proctocolectomy with Ileal Pouch-Anal Anastomosis (TPA+IPAA)
Total Proctocolectomy with mucosectomy with hand-sewn IPAA
Total abdominal colectomy with very low Hartmann closure with end ileostomy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Total Proctocolectomy with Ileal Pouch-Anal Anastomosis

¬†

Explanation:

Total Proctocolectomy with Ileal Pouch-Anal Anastomosis (TPA + IPAA)

Indications:

  • Definitive treatment for ulcerative colitis, especially in young patients.
  • Eliminates risk of colorectal cancer and colitis-related symptoms.

¬†

Typically done in two stages:

  • Proctocolectomy and ileal pouch creation.
  • Closure of the ileostomy after pouch healing.

Proctocolectomy (First Stage)

Remove the colon and rectum.

Preserve the anal canal.

‚Üì

Ileal Pouch Creation

Create a J-shaped ileal pouch from a segment of the ileum.

Connect the pouch to the anal canal (ileal pouch-anal anastomosis).

‚Üì

Anastomosis and Ileostomy

Anastomose the J-pouch to the anal canal.

Perform a covering loop ileostomy to divert intestinal contents and protect the pouch.

‚Üì

Post-operative Imaging

Conduct a Gastrografin contrast enema to confirm the integrity and healing of the pouch.

‚Üì

Closure of Ileostomy (Second Stage)

Close the ileostomy once pouch healing is confirmed through imaging.

‚Üì

Post-surgical Outcomes

Monitor for adjustment to stool frequency and management of minor issues like urgency or fecal incontinence, which usually improve over time.

¬†

¬†


¬†

TPC + End Ileostomy (Option A) is preferred for older patients and patients with fecal incontinence.

¬†

TPC + mucosectomy with hand-sewn IPAA (Option C) is a procedure done in case of the presence of rectal dysplasia.

¬†

Total abdominal colectomy with very low Hartmann closure with end ileostomy (Option D) is done in more debilitating cases and those who can‚Äôt tolerate long duration of surgery. The rectum is spared here.

¬†

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a history of chronic abdominal pain, frequent bloody diarrhea, and an urgent need to defecate. Colonoscopy reveals continuous inflammation starting from the rectum and extending through the colon. Despite receiving the highest doses of medical therapy, the symptoms have worsened. Which of the following would not be considered an indication for surgery in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Enteroenteric fistula

¬†

Explanation:

  • Surgery is the preferred choice of treatment in case of complications of Crohn‚Äôs disease such as tenesmus, multiple bowel movements, fulminant colitis, failure of maximum medical management and those with poor quality of life as a result of poor nutritional status.
  • However, enteroenteric fistulas do not require surgery unless they are accompanied by notable symptoms, such as obstruction or significant discomfort.
  • Abdominal pain caused by obstruction is also regarded as an indication for surgery.

¬†

Indications of surgery in IBD:

¬†

Ulcerative colitis

Crohn‚Äôs disease:
  • Failure of maximum medical therapy (Option A)
  • Poor quality of life due to tenesmus, urgency, and low body weight.
  • Multiple bowel movements (Option B), poor nutritional status, and weak physical health.
  • Growth retardation in children or adolescents;
  • Fulminant colitis (Option C). Some of these cases may also have toxic megacolon.
  • Severe colitis leads to chronic ileus and a dilated colon, both leading to an increased risk of perforation.
  • Significant GI bleeding
  • Associated sclerosing cholangitis
  • Presence of colonic dysplasia or cancer in colonoscopic surveillance (chronic UC > 8 years)
  • Perianal disease not responding to treatment.
  • Severe extra-intestinal disease
  • Children with failure to thrive
  • Symptoms of obstruction secondary to fibrostenosing Crohn's disease
  • Perforated Crohn‚Äôs disease with associated abscess or fistula
  • Severe abdominal pain with obstruction
  • Cancer or dysplasia
  • Isolated terminal ileal disease
  • Recurrent disease
  • Incidental finding of Crohn‚Äôs during an appendectomy


¬†

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis has achieved clinical remission with a biologic agent. Which of the following drugs is used in the maintenance therapy for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Adalimumab

¬†

Explanation:

Adalimumab is an anti-TNF agent used in the maintenance therapy of moderate to severe ulcerative colitis. It helps maintain remission after the initial response.

¬†

Aspect

Mild to Moderate UC

Moderate to Severe UC

Goals of Therapy

Induce and maintain clinical remission.

Achieve and maintain glucocorticoid-free remission, prevent relapse.

Initial Treatment

5-ASA compounds (e.g., mesalamine, sulfasalazine) or topical corticosteroids.

5-ASA compounds, corticosteroids, or biologics (e.g., anti-TNF agents, vedolizumab).

Maintenance Therapy

5-ASA compounds; consider thiopurines for non-responders or relapsers.

Biologics (e.g., anti-TNF agents- infliximab, adalimumab; vedolizumab), thiopurines, or small molecules (e.g., JAK inhibitors).

Lab Monitoring

CBC, liver tests every 3-4 months; electrolytes and renal function annually.

Endoscopic Evaluation

Not routinely required unless symptoms persist.

Colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy every 6 months, or based on clinical need.

Inflammatory Markers

CRP and fecal calprotectin every 3-4 months if used.

Relapse Management
  • Optimize dosage, consider switching therapies if necessary.
  • Evaluate for co-existing conditions and adherence.

Specific Therapies

Thiopurines: Consider if non-responsive to 5-ASA.
  • Anti-TNF Agents
  • Vedolizumab
  • Ustekinumab
  • Mirikizumab
  • JAK Inhibitors (Tofacitinib, Upadacitinib)
  • S1P Receptor Modulators (Ozanimod, Etrasimod)

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a low rectal tumor and requires bowel diversion. The surgeon is considering the type of stoma to be created. Which of the following indications best matches the need for an ileostomy rather than a colostomy?

choices.text: To relieve bowel obstruction when resection is not feasible.
To protect a distal anastomosis after low anterior resection.
To manage inflammatory diseases with severe perianal disease.
Permanent fecal diversion following total colectomy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Permanent fecal diversion following total colectomy

¬†

Explanation:

Permanent fecal diversion following total colectomy is one of the major indications for Ileostomy.

  • An end ileostomy is indicated following total colectomy for conditions such as Rectal carcinoma or familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).
  • This results in a permanent stoma, where the ileum is brought to the surface, and the patient manages the stoma for life.
  • The absence of the colon necessitates this approach, making it specific to conditions involving the entire colon removal.

¬†

A colostomy can be used to relieve obstruction when resection isn't possible¬†(Option A), such as in cases of obstructing rectal cancer or sigmoid volvulus. It helps divert stool away from the obstruction site.

¬†

A colostomy is commonly used to protect a distal anastomosis¬†(Option B), especially after rectal surgery, by diverting fecal flow and allowing the anastomosis to heal without the risk of contamination from fecal material.

¬†

While ileostomy may sometimes be used in Crohn's and other inflammatory diseases, colostomy can also be indicated, particularly when the disease is localized to the colon and perianal regions¬†(Option C). It helps manage fecal diversion in severe cases, allowing perianal lesions to heal.

¬†

Feature

Ileostomy

Colostomy

Location

Typically located in the right iliac fossa

Typically located in the left iliac fossa

Stool Consistency

Usually results in liquid or semi-liquid stool

Produces a more formed stool

Spout

Ileostomy is usually spouted

Colostomy is usually flush

Use
  • To defunction the rest of the bowel in order to protect a distal anastomosis
  • To evacuate stool from the body if the entire colon has been removed (such as in colorectal cancer, IBD)
  • To relieve bowel obstruction
  • To protect a distal anastomosis or allow healing away from the faecal flow
  • Following resection when anastomosis is unsafe or not possible
  • To relieve obstruction when resection is not feasible
  • To reduce disease activity (e.g. Crohn‚Äôs disease)
  • To allow alternative bowel control (incontinence)

Fluid and electrolyte problems

More likely

Less likely

Appliances

Requires bags that often need to be emptied frequently due to the liquid consistency of the stool

Uses appliances that may be changed as needed, depending on the type of colostomy and stool consistency

Image

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 39-year-old male with a 12-year history of ulcerative colitis presents with worsening symptoms despite maximum medical therapy. He experiences >10 bowel movements per day, urgency, tenesmus, and significant weight loss. Biopsies show high-grade dysplasia. The surgical team plans a total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA). What is the primary goal of the planned surgery for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Curative

¬†

Explanation:

  • The primary goal of the planned surgery, which is a total proctocolectomy with Ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA), is to cure ulcerative colitis.
  • IPAA has become the most popular procedure for Ulcerative colitis not responding to medical therapy as well as for patients requiring colectomy for the presence of dysplasia.
  • It significantly improves the patient's quality of life and effectively cures the colonic manifestation of ulcerative colitis‚Äã.

¬†

Palliative surgery (Option A) relieves symptoms without addressing the underlying cause.¬†While it may be used to manage severe symptoms in some cases, the primary goal of a proctocolectomy in ulcerative colitis is to remove the diseased bowel and provide a cure, not just symptom relief‚Äã.

¬†

Achieving remission (Option B) refers to controlling the symptoms and inflammation with medication. Surgery, in this case, is intended to cure the disease by removing the entire diseased colon and rectum, not just to put the disease into remission‚Äã

¬†

Maintenance (Option D) typically refers to ongoing medical therapy to manage the disease. In the context of high-grade dysplasia in ulcerative colitis, the surgery is performed with a curative intent to prevent cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding ulcerative colitis is correct?

choices.text: Backwash ileitis, where there is secondary inflammation in the terminal ileum, is a common finding in all patients with ulcerative colitis.
Extraintestinal manifestations such as arthritis are more likely to occur in patients with proctitis alone.
8 bloody stools per day and associated joint pain are classified as moderate ulcerative colitis.
Fulminant ulcerative colitis is characterized by >10 bowel movements daily, continuous bleeding, and evidence of systemic toxicity.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fulminant ulcerative colitis is characterized by >10 bowel movements daily, continuous bleeding, and evidence of systemic toxicity.

¬†

Explanation:

  • Fulminant ulcerative colitis is associated with >10 bowel movements daily, fever, tachycardia, continuous bleeding, anemia, hypoalbuminemia, abdominal tenderness and distension, the need for blood transfusion and, in the most severe cases, progressive colonic dilation (toxic megacolon).
  • This is a very significant finding, suggestive of disintegrative colitis, and an indication for emergency surgery if colonic perforation is to be avoided.

¬†

Backwash ileitis¬†(Option A) is a secondary inflammation in the terminal ileum, seen in some patients with pancolitis but not all ulcerative colitis patients.

  • It involves retrograde inflammation extending 2‚Äì3 cm into the terminal ileum from the colon.
  • Risk factors include extensive colitis and primary sclerosing cholangitis.
  • Biopsies help distinguish backwash ileitis from Crohn's disease-related ileitis.

¬†

If inflammation is confined to the rectum (proctitis), there are usually no systemic symptoms, and extra-alimentary manifestations are rare (Option B).

  • The main symptoms are rectal bleeding, tenesmus and mucous discharge.

¬†

According to the severity classification, a patient with > 6 bloody stools per day and evidence of systemic illness, such as joint pain, would be classified as having severe ulcerative colitis, not moderate.

¬†

Truelove and Witts Severity Classification for Ulcerative Colitis:

Severity

Stool Frequency

Systemic Symptoms and signs

Mild

<4 stools/day

No systemic signs of toxicity

Moderate¬†

(Option¬†C)

>4 stools/day

Fever, abdominal pain, Elevated ESR, CRP

Severe

>6 stools/day

Fever, tachycardia, anemia, systemic illness, hypoalbuminuria, Elevated ESR, CRP

Fulminant

>10 stools/day

Continuous bleeding, fever, tachycardia, abdominal tenderness & distension, ‚ÄúToxic megacolon‚Äù (progressive colonic dilation, an indication for emergency surgery) in severe cases

questions.text:
A 38-year-old patient with a history of chronic diarrhea and rectal bleeding undergoes a barium enema for evaluation. The radiological image shows changes in the colonic mucosa. Based on the findings of the barium enema, which of the following radiological features is most indicative of Ulcerative colitis (UC)?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Narrowed, constricted colon with a "hose pipe" appearance
Multiple deep ulcers with surrounding inflammation
Discontinuous patches of inflammation with normal segments in between

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Narrowed, constricted colon with a "hose pipe" appearance

¬†

Explanation:

Ulcerative colitis is characterized by the loss of haustrations and narrowing of the colon, which can appear like a "hose pipe" on a barium enema.

¬†

¬†

Diagnostic and Investigatory Methods for UC:

  • Colonoscopy: Primary method; examines the entire colon, includes biopsy to confirm diagnosis.
  • Histology:
    • Biopsies show significant inflammation, with polymorphonuclear leukocytes, goblet cell depletion, and crypt abscesses.
    • UC inflammation is confined to the mucosal surface.
  • Barium Enema:
    • Shows loss of haustrations, narrowed colon - Garden hose appearance/ Pipestem colon/Lead pipe sign/ Stove pipe sign
    • mucosal changes
    • pseudopolyps
    • Avoided in fulminant cases.
  • Sigmoidoscopy and Biopsy: Visualizes rectum and lower colon, and allows biopsy for diagnostic confirmation.
  • Plain X-ray Abdomen: Identifies complications like bowel obstruction, toxic megacolon, and perforation.
  • CRP Test: Elevated during acute UC phase.
  • pANCA Test: Helps differentiate UC from Crohn's disease; present in ~85% of UC patients.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with persistent and worsening chronic diarrhea, rectal bleeding, and abdominal pain for the past several months. An endoscopic examination reveals continuous mucosal inflammation starting at the rectum and extending proximally. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of ulcerative colitis (UC) and helps differentiate it from Crohn's disease?

choices.text: Continuous inflammation starting from the rectum
Presence of granulomas in the mucosal layer

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Continuous inflammation starting from the rectum

¬†

Explanation:

Ulcerative colitis is characterized by inflammation that begins at the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner without skip lesions.

  • This differentiates it from Crohn‚Äôs disease, which often presents with patchy inflammation and skip lesions.

¬†

Ulcerative Colitis (UC)

  • UC is an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) characterized by chronic inflammation primarily affecting the mucosal layer of the colon.
  • Unlike Crohn's disease, which can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract and involves deeper bowel layers, UC is limited to the colon and involves only the mucosal layer.
    ¬†

Contributing factors
  • Defective mucin production: Mucosal immunological reactions
  • Autoimmune factors (Cytotoxic T cells, anticolon antibodies)
  • HLA DR2 association
  • Family history
  • Cow's milk allergy
  • Stress and lifestyle associations

Protective factors
  • Appendicectomy
  • Smoking

Sites of involvement
  • UC is confined to the large intestine.
  • Always involves the rectum; extends proximally continuously.
  • Extent of involvement:
    • Proctitis/Proctosigmoiditis (Limited to the rectum and sigmoid colon)
    • Left-Sided Colitis
    • Pancolitis (Entire colon)

Colonoscopy Findings
  • Continuous inflammation from the dentate line of the rectum and extends proximally.
  • Initially, mucosa appears erythematous, granular, or roughened; it worsens over time.
  • Ulcers are long, serpentine, covered in fibrin, with a "bear claw" appearance.
  • Significant bleeding can occur due to ulcer erosion into blood vessels.

¬†

Microscopic Findings
  • Inflammation limited to the mucosal layer
  • Polymorphonuclear leukocytes in lamina propria.
  • Depletion of mucin in goblet cells.
  • Crypt abscesses contain inflammatory cells within Lieberk√ºhn crypts.
  • No granulomas, deep fissural ulcers, or transmural lymphoid aggregates.

¬†

¬†

¬†

questions.text: Which extraintestinal manifestation is most commonly associated with Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Erythema nodosum

¬†

Explanation:

The most common extraintestinal manifestation of Crohn‚Äôs disease is skin lesions.

  • Specifically, erythema nodosum and pyoderma gangrenosum are the most common skin conditions.
  • Erythema nodosum is characterised by painful, red nodules usually located on the shin of tibia.
  • Extra intestinal manifestations can occur in about 30% of Crohn's patients.

1. Skin

  • Erythema multiforme
  • Pyoderma gangrenosum

2. Eyes

  • Iritis

  • Conjunctivitis

3. Blood

  • Anemia
  • Thrombocytosis
  • Phlebothrombosis
  • Arterial thrombosis

4. Joints

  • Peripheral Arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Sacroiliitis

  • Non-specific Hepatitis

  • Most common cutaneous manifestation of IBD - Erythema Nodosum
  • Erythema Nodosum

    2. Persistence of Erythema Nodosum - Indicates inadequate control of IBD

questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient with a history of long-standing Crohn's disease presents for a follow-up examination. An abdominal X-ray with barium contrast is performed to evaluate the current state of the small bowel. Based on the barium radiographic image provided, which of the following signs is depicted below?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) String Sign of Kantor

¬†

Explanation:

String Sign of Kantor is associated with long-standing Crohn‚Äôs disease. It is characterised by multiple filling defects seen in barium studies due to kinking and fibrosis of the bowel, especially the terminal ileum.

¬†

¬†

¬†

Radiological signs of Crohn‚Äôs disease

String sign of Kantor

Cicatrization of the ileum, which is a narrowing of the ileum caused by scarring.

Fat halo sign:¬†Low attenuation of submucosal fat around the bowel

Rose thorn or raspberry thorn appearance: Linear transmural ulcers

Vascular jejunization of ileum: Comb sign

¬†

Apple-Core Sign (Option B) is typically associated with colorectal cancer and presents as a constricted lesion with an "apple-core" appearance.

Lead-pipe appearance (Option C) indicates ulcerative colitis, in which the colon appears smooth and rigid due to the loss of haustral folds.

Bird-beak sign (Option D) is seen in esophageal conditions such as achalasia, where the esophagus narrows like a bird's beak.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female with a known diagnosis of Crohn's disease presents with symptoms of abdominal pain, weight loss, and intermittent diarrhea. Imaging studies reveal significant inflammation and strictures in the gastrointestinal tract. Which part of the gastrointestinal tract is most commonly affected by Crohn's disease, leading to ulcers and strictures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ileum

¬†

Explanation:

The ileum is the most common site affected by Crohn's disease, where complications such as enterocutaneous fistulas, enterovesical fistulas, ulcers, strictures, and carcinoma frequently occur.

  • Crohn's disease is a chronic, transmural inflammatory condition of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, most commonly affecting the ileum.
  • It presents with insidious onset, chronic diarrhea (with loose bowel movements, rarely containing blood, pus, or mucus.), intermittent colicky abdominal pain (often in the right lower quadrant- mimics appendicitis), systemic symptoms like weight loss, and low-grade fever.
  • The disease can affect any part of the GI tract (mouth to anus) but most frequently involves the small intestine and colon with discontinuous "skip areas."

¬†

Complications:

¬†

Complication

Description

Obstruction

Acute inflammation, edema, chronic fibrotic lesions

Perforation

This leads to fistulas, localized abscesses, and rarely generalized peritonitis

Toxic Megacolon

Colonic dilation, abdominal tenderness, fever, leukocytosis

Bleeding

Chronic, indolent, possible massive bleeding with duodenal involvement

questions.text:
A 35-year-old patient presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. A resection of the terminal ileum is performed, and the findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of this disease?


{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Continuous mucosal lesions and crypt abscesses
Superficial ulceration and loss of haustrations

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cobblestone appearance and transmural inflammation

Explanation:

  • The given image of the respected terminal ileum shows a Cobblestone appearance along with longitudinal ulcerations, characteristic of Crohn‚Äôs disease.
  • Cobblestone appearance is a hallmark of Crohn's disease, resulting from deep ulcerations and intervening areas of normal mucosa.
  • Transmural inflammation, which affects all layers of the bowel wall, is a characteristic microscopic finding in Crohn's disease.

Continuous mucosal lesions and crypt abscesses (Option A) are more characteristic of Ulcerative Colitis (UC).

  • UC typically shows continuous lesions starting from the rectum and crypt abscesses confined to the mucosa and submucosa.
  • Crohn‚Äôs disease, in contrast, shows skip lesions and transmural involvement.

Superficial ulceration and loss of haustrations (Option C), leading to a "lead pipe" appearance seen on barium enema, are more indicative of Ulcerative Colitis rather than Crohn‚Äôs disease.

  • Crohn‚Äôs disease involves deeper, transmural ulcerations.

Pseudopolyps (Option D) are often seen in UC due to repeated cycles of ulceration and healing.

  • Mucosal inflammation alone, without transmural involvement, is more typical of UC. Crohn's disease involves deeper layers, creating a cobblestone appearance on endoscopy.

Differences between Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis

¬†

Feature

Crohn's Disease

Ulcerative Colitis

Gross Morphology
  • Skip lesions: Involves terminal ileum and colon
  • Cobblestone appearance: Transmural inflammation results in cobblestone mucosa
  • Continuous lesions: Affects colon in continuous manner starting from rectum
  • Presence of pseudopolyps


¬†

Microscopic Morphology

Transmural inflammation: Involves all layers of the bowel wall

¬†

Non-caseating granulomas: Characteristic finding

Mucosal inflammation: Confined to mucosa and submucosa

¬†

Crypt abscesses: Neutrophil infiltration into crypts

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and recent weight loss. Correct Answer: A) NOD2/CARD15 gene mutation, smoking

Explanation:

  • The given presentation of chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and recent weight loss, with tenderness in the right lower quadrant, along with patchy inflammation in the terminal ileum with skip lesions on colonoscopy, is consistent with Crohn‚Äôs disease.
  • The NOD2/CARD15 gene mutation on chromosome 16 is strongly associated with Crohn's disease. Smoking worsens the condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman undergoes an emergency ileostomy following bowel obstruction. Two weeks postoperatively, she presents with increased pain and swelling around the stoma site. On examination, a bulge is noted adjacent to the stoma. The stoma itself appears healthy, with no signs of necrosis or ischemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Parastomal Hernia

¬†

Explanation:

  • A parastomal hernia occurs when the abdominal contents protrude through the defect in the abdominal wall created for the stoma.
  • It typically presents as a bulge around the stoma and can lead to discomfort, pain, and cosmetic concerns‚Äã.
  • This complication is more common with ileostomies due to the increased intra-abdominal pressure and the nature of the bowel segment used.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient undergoes emergency abdominal surgery for a perforated sigmoid diverticulitis with peritonitis.
